_exec_summary.SummaryText:
40CFR Part 68 Risk Management Program Executive Summary
Genencor International Wisconsin, Inc.
IFF Nutrition & Biosciences

The Genencor International Wisconsin Beloit site is wholly owned by International Flavors & Fragrances, Inc. (IFF) based in New York, New York.  It is an industrial biotechnology facility that is ISO-9001:2015 and ISO-14001:2015 certified facility that employs approximately 85 people and operates under a team-based organizational structure. 

The facility manufactures enzymes through a fermentation-based process. Enzymes are chemicals comprised of large proteins, and have been used in the food and detergent manufacturing industries for many years.  The site's manufactured enzymes are primarily intended for use in the grain processing industry.   The facility operates a continuous 24-hour-per-day process and has on-site Maintenance and Laboratory support.  Staff support includes site Management, Safety, Health & Environmental, Engineering, Purchasing, Finance, and Systems personnel.

Chemical Process Safety & Regulated Substance
The Beloit facility adheres to IFF's corporate Process Safety and Risk Management standards.  These standards include 14 elements of process safety and Management Leadership & Commitment.  Each element includes policies and procedures that the site is held to via 1st and 2nd Party audit programs.  Management at the Beloit facility is committed to the implementation of IFF's Process Safety and Risk Management standard and has appointed an RMP Leader and a team of element leaders to oversee and lead the implementation of each element and the appropriate policies.  Management is committed to employee involvement and participation in many activities such as Process Hazards Analysis, Management of Change, Operation Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Emergency Planning & Response.

The Beloit facility stores 29.4% aqueous ammonia (ammonium hydroxide) and uses the chemical in the enzyme manufacturing process.  The 29.4% aque

ous ammonia process is covered by the EPA Risk Management Plan rule.

Site commitment to Safety, Health, & Environment includes the following examples:

The Safety, Health, & Environment budget is established to provide:
Appropriate and adequate personal protective equipment
Appropriate post-offer and annual medical examinations
Training
Air monitoring equipment and analysis
Hazardous waste pick-up for a small quantity hazardous waste generator

The role of this support team includes the following:
Help identify, prioritize and address physical hazards through plant safety audits
Help communicate impacts to employees
Help others to act

Member responsibilities include:
Represent their functional areas as members of the Safety Committee
Facilitate safety program implementation
Help to establish minimum safe work practices
Participate in safety walk-arounds
Communicate back to their functional teams

Process Safety Steering Committee and Process Safety Element Committee are in place.
The role of these support teams includes the following:
Implementation of the IFF PSM Program
Providing and executing implementation strategies
Review of process safety metrics
Review audit results and coordinate implementation action

The IFF Core Values and Commitment to Safety, Health, and Environment guide us through sustainable site efforts.

The IFF Commitment Safety, Health, and the Environment:
Through our Commitment to safety, health, and environment excellence, we affirm to all our stakeholders, including our employees, customers, shareholders, and the public, that we will work collaboratively to bring sustainable, market-driven and innovative solutions to solve some of the world's biggest challenges, making lives better, safer, and healthier for people everywhere.  We will implement those strategies that build successful businesses and achieve the greatest benefit for all our stakeholders with respect and care for the environment without compromising the ability of future gener

ations to meet their needs. 
We will continuously improve our practices in light of advances in technology and new understandings in safety, health, and environmental science.  We will make consistent measurable progress in implementing this Commitment throughout our worldwide operations and support Responsible Care as a key program to achieve this Commitment.
New employees attend approximately 7 hours of initial safety training, which includes chemical awareness training as well as various OSHA and EPA-required information.  Job task training is ongoing for each employee and occurs with co-worker trainers utilizing training manuals and SOP's.  IFF believes in being proactive in its training endeavors and strives to encourage employees to attend specific training associated with their job duties that go above and beyond the basic job requirements.
Capital projects deemed necessary for environmental, health & safety reasons are implemented and supported through the capital expenditure process.

Emergency Response
The site's Emergency Action Plan addresses how employees, contractors, and visitors shall respond to emergencies.  All employees are trained in the Emergency Action Plan as a part of the established initial safety training for new employees and is being refreshed annually.  The Emergency Action Plan outlines the responsibility of involved personnel during an incident, discusses the On-Scene Commander duties, gives instructions for securing off-site emergency response, addresses internal and external notifications including the media and public, and outlines emergency procedures for general emergency response.

Specific procedures on actions to take for incidental spills and emergencies related to anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia.   All employees are provided training as a part of the established initial safety training for new employees and is being refreshed annually.  These procedures address recognizing and reporting small spills and emergencies, PPE

and tools for use in investigating and mitigating small spills, and specific instructions for site evacuation.

Five Year Accident History
The aqueous ammonia process has not had any EPA reportable incidents.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
We strive for continuous improvement of our safety systems and practices as well as maintenance and production.  Recommendations from internal PHAs and auditing will be implemented to further improve safety and safe operations for IFF's aqueous ammonia system.
